resources.string: Click the link to go to the National Park Service website for the Shenandoah Valley. https://www.nps.gov/shen/index.htm
Maps have suggested ability descriptors. Shenandoah\'s Hiking Difficulty is determined by a numerical rating using the following formula:

Elevation Gain x 2 x distance (in miles). The product's square root is the numerical rating. For example, a 10-mile hike that gains 2,200 feet in elevation: 
2,200 x 2=4,400 
4,400 x 10 = 44,000 
Square root of 44,000=209.8

The hike\'s numerical rating is then tied to one of five descriptors: Easiest, Moderate, Moderately Strenuous, Strenuous, Very Strenuous. \nThe example hike (above) would be rated Very Strenuous. \nThere are a few exceptions to the formula\'s validity, such as Dark Hollow Falls. Although its numeric rating of 36.3 puts it in the \"Easiest\" range, its steepness over such a short distance warrants a \"Moderate.\"
Numerical Rating: less than 50 \nA hike that is generally suitable for anyone who enjoys walking. Mostly level or with a slight incline. Generally less than 3 miles.

Numerical Rating: 50-100 \nA moderate hike is generally suitable for novice hikers who want a bit of a challenge. The terrain will involve a moderate incline and may have some steeper sections. Generally 3 to 5 miles.
Numerical Rating: 100â€“150 \nModerately Strenuous hikes will generally be challenging for an unconditioned person. The terrain will involve a steady and often steep incline. Generally 5 to 8 miles.

Numerical Rating: 150-200 \nStrenuous hikes will challenge most hikers. The hike will generally be longer and steeper, but may be deemed "Strenuous" because of the elevation gain. Generally 7 to 10 miles.

Numerical Rating : greater than 200 \nOnly well-conditioned and well-prepared hikers should attempt very strenuous hikes. The hike will generally be long and steep, and may include rock scrambling, stream crossings, and other challenging terrain. Generally 8 miles and over.

1.5 miles per hour for easiest trails. 
1.4 mph for moderate trails. 
1.3 mph for moderately strenuous trails. 
1.2 mph for strenuous and very strenuous trails. 
This is hiking time and does not take into consideration fitness, exploration, rest, contemplation, etc.
